results.title: Third dimension
results.brief_description: In this survey of modern Canadian sculpture, man’s desire to give a third-dimensional form to his image is seen both in the child’s mudpies and in the greatest commemorative monuments. Techniques of the sculptor’s art - carving in wood and stone, clay modelling, making a plaster mold for metal casting - are demonstrated by leading Canadian sculptors, in a survey which extends from totem poles and early French woodcarving to the great war memorial on Vimy Ridge. Included are Jacobine Jones, Frances Loring, Donald Stewart, Louis Parent and Dora Weschler, as well as Emmanuel Hahn with his designs for coins.

results.title: Thinking about drinking
results.brief_description: Presents the facts about alcoholic beverages with emphasis on their effects on the nervous system and behaviour. An alcoholic is a person who drinks so much that it interferes with their work and health, and alcoholism is a disease which constitutes a major health problem.

results.title: Think twice: the persuasion game
results.brief_description: This film presents vignettes which dramatise ways in which the power of persuasion is used to influence the public. Appeals are made to one’s emotions. Fear, vanity, pride, justice and one’s desire to belong are utilised. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Think of the future
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information for European Productivity Agency and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A cartoon contrasting improved modern conditions of work with the “good old days” when working and living conditions were in fact very much inferior. Only by increased production can the present high living standard be maintained and improved; to this end co-operation between workers and management is essential.

results.title: Things afoot
results.creator_credit: Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: Envisages a world without shoes to prove how footwear is indispensable in modern everyday life. A visit to a shoe factory illustrates the many complicated machines used in the manufacture of footwear. Scenes at a technical school show how the young apprentice receives theoretical and practical training in the manufacture of shoes. The concluding section of the film lists the advantages of employment in the shoe trade; stability of employment, welfare schemes, recreational facilities, wages etc.

results.title: Thin end of the wedge (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A program that looks at a week in the life of a young wood craftsman, Barry Mills. He struggles to make a living from his work, rejecting the temptation to produce what a businessman wants rather than what he wants to do. He seeks advice from an experienced country wood worker and finally exhibits his work.

results.title: Thief of Sydney
results.creator_credit: Toby Zoates and Australian Film Commission. Creative Development Branch
results.brief_description: Animated film about a young unemployed man who dreams about adventures in a futuristic, post holocaust Sydney where he still manages to face his hopes and fears and to overcome obstacles. A discussion starter for unemployment, the nuclear debate, adolescence and society, and fears of the future.

results.title: They would elope
results.brief_description: A father tricks his daughter into eloping with her lover and then celebrates her wedding upon their return. Cast includes Billy Quirk, Mary Pickford, James Kirkwood, Kate Bruce, Mack Sennett. Silent film with no intertitles.
